titleStmt.title: On the Passivity of Linear Delay Systems

analytic.title: On the Passivity of Linear Delay Systems

biblStruct.note: received March 23, 1999; revised December 1, 1999 and May 29, 2000. Recommended by Associate Editor C. Scherer.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This note presents some sufficient conditions for a linear system with (point or distributed) delay in the state to be passive. Passivity based (memoryless) stabilization of linear delay systems is also addressed. The proposed approach is based on a Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional construction. Numerical examples are also included.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Stability and control of linear systems with delayed state are problems of recurring interest since the existence of a delay in a system representation may induce instability, oscillations or bad performances for the closed-loop schemes [11], [19].

The passivity theory intimately related to the circuit analysis methods [3], [2] has received a lot of attention from the control community since the 70s (see [10], [29], [30], [17], [28], or [26], to cite only a few).

Although there exists a lot of results in (finite-dimensional) linear or nonlinear systems, the delay case (state or input) has not been fully investigated. Thus, in [15] and [16], an infinite-dimensional based approach is used for deriving (frequency-based) sufficient conditions. An energy based idea coming from nonlinear passivity analysis is proposed in [25].
Furthermore, the passivity of an appropriate linear system is used to derive some robust stability conditions for a class of time-varying delay systems in [27].

In this note, we shall consider the passivity problem of a linear system described by differential equations with delayed state. The interconnection schemes with passive systems will be also treated. Both point and point + distributed delay [14] cases are addressed.

The interest of the passivity approach for time-delay systems is twofold: first, to extend notions, techniques and results from the finite-dimensional case to some special class of infinite-dimensional systems for which finite-dimensional interpretations are possible (state vector evolutions in Euclidian spaces [22]). Second, since in the finite-dimensional case, the passivity of the interconnection scheme of passive systems may be used to control a large class of nonlinear systems, it seems that this technique may simplify, in some cases, the memoryless control problem of time-delay systems. In other words, if we have a delay system that is positive-real or that can be made positive-real through feedback, the proposed controller synthesis is simple and will use the fact that the system is passive to render the closed-loop robust with respect to uncertainties provided that the system remains passive. As potential applications, one may mention the stability and stabilization schemes of electrical networks, where a transmission delay is inherent to the application, or in the control of teleoperators [20], [1], [5]. Indeed, Niemeyer and Slotine [20] pointed out the presence of some force reflections in bilateral teleoperating schemes. By considering a simple transmission of the slave interaction force, a transmission delay will appear with, eventually, some loss of dynamic properties (passivity, exponential stability) [1], [5].

The proposed approach is based on an appropriate Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional construction [9], [11], [22] (for further comments, see also [23]). The corresponding results may include or not delay information and are expressed in terms of solutions of some algebraic Riccati equations. Note that the results presented in this paper can be extended to the multiple or time-varying delays case by an appropriate choice of the Lyapunov functional (see also [23], [22]). For the sake of simplicity, we have not addressed such techniques here.

The paper is organized as follows: the point delay case is addressed in Section II. Interconnection schemes are presented in Section III. Extensions to point + distributed delay systems are considered in Section IV. Section V contains two numerical examples (scalar and second order). Concluding remarks in Section VI end the note. The notations used are standard.

div.head: II. ON THE PASSIVITY OF A SYSTEM WITH STATE DELAY
div.p: Consider the following system with pointwise delay:
div.formula: _ x(t) = Ax(t) + A1x(t 0 ) + Bu(t) y(t) = Cx(t) (1)
div.p: with an appropriate initial condition (vector-valued function) defined on [0; 0] and taking values in R n : C([0; 0]; R n ) (x 2 R n ). The signals y 2 R p , u 2 R p are the output and the input of the system, > 0 denotes the delay, and A; A1 2 R n2n , B; C T 2 R n2p are known real matrices. Denote U and Y the sets of admissible trajectory in R p for the input, and the output respectively.

Definition 1 [26]: An operator H: U 7 ! Y is said to be passive if t 0 u(s) > y(s) ds 0 2 for some 2 R and for all t, where (u; y) 2 U 2 Y denotes an admissible trajectory described by y(s) = H(s)u(s).

Definition 2 [26]: An operator H: U 7 ! Y is said to be strictly passive if there exist "1 0, "2 0, "1 + "2 > 0, such that t 0 u(s) > y(s) ds 0 for some 2 R, 8 t, where (u; y) 2 U 2 Y denotes an admissible trajectory described by: y(s) = H(s)u(s).
The system is said to be input-strictly passive if " 1 > 0 and output- strictly passive if " 2 > 0.

Let us note that (1) will be (strictly) passive if it satisfies the above inequalities for all initial conditions defined by a vector valued function on [0; 0]. In the sequel, we shall define some sufficient passivity conditions for various linear delay systems including pointwise or distributed delays, based on a finite-dimensional interpretation of the vector state [23], [22].
The main result can be stated as follows.
Lemma 1: If there exist positive-definite matrices P > 0 and S > 0 and a scalar 0 such that 0 1 = A T P + P A + P A 1 S 01 A T 1 P + S < C T C C = B T P

This gives us an extra degree of freedom for choosing P and S in (3) since the inequality in (3) becomes more restrictive for = 0. We can expect to be able to stabilize system (1) using an appropriate passive controller as will be seen in the next section. Note that, for < 0, the system is output-strictly passive but this imposes stronger restrictions on the system [see (3)].

Remark 2: The Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional candidate ( 5) has been already used in the control literature for deriving delay-independent (no information on the delay size) (closed-loop) stability results. An overview on existing techniques and further comments can be found in [23]. Also, note that the proposed result is delay-independent.

Proof: From (1) and the above conditions, we have where 0 is given by (3) and I(x(t); x(t 0 )) = [S 01 A T 1 P x(t) 0 x(t 0 )] T 2S[S 01 A T 1 P x(t) 0 x(t 0 )]: Note that V (t) is a positive-definite function and I(x(t); x(t0)) 0 for all the trajectories of the system. div.head: III. INTERCONNECTION OF PASSIVE SYSTEMS
div.p: Let us consider the block interconnection depicted in Fig. 1. Assume without loss of generality that H 1 represents system (1) and H 2 is a "controller" which is input-strictly passive as defined above, i.e., for some " > 0 for all t. The transfer H 2 can be a finite-dimensional linear system for example. For the sake of simplicity, we will consider H2 to be an asymptotically stable strictly proper linear system. Next, we will show that the controller satisfying the above property will stabilize system (1). Proposition 1: Consider the feedback interconnection in Fig. 1. If the block H 2 is strictly proper asymptotically stable and input-strictly passive, and the block H1 satisfies Lemma 1, then 1) all the signals are in L2.;
div.formula: t 0 u 2 (s) > y 2 (s)ds 0 2 2 + " t 0 u 2 (s) > u 2 (s)ds for some 2 R(8)
div.p: 2) the closed-loop system is stable.
Proof: The first statement follows naturally. Indeed, from Lemma 1, the interconnection scheme and ( 8) we have u2 = y1 y 2 = 0u 1 :

Therefore, from ( 4) and ( 8), we have (u = u 1 and y = y 1 in Lemma 1) 0 = where 2 = (1=2)V (0) + 2 2 . If " 0 (1=2) > 0 then y 1 is in L 2 . Since H2 is an asymptotically stable linear system with an L2 input, it follows that the corresponding output y2 and also the corresponding state (saying x c ) are also L 2 \ L 1 and converge to zero (see Desoer and Vidyasagar [4], van der Schaft [26], and Lozano et al. [18]).

Since y 1 2 L 2 \ L 1 , and since the solution of the closed-loop system is smooth (see the step-by-step method for delay systems in Halanay [8]), the signals have "no peaks" and thus, y 1 ! 0, q.e.d.

div.head: IV. EXTENSION TO A SYSTEM WITH DISTRIBUTED STATE DELAY
div.p: Let us consider the following class of distributional convolution systems:
div.formula: _ x(t) = A 3 x(t) + Bu(t) y(t) = Cx(t) (13)
div.p: where A denotes a distribution of order zero on some compact support [0; 0] [32]. Choosing A = A() + A1( 0 1) + A2()

where () represents the Dirac delta functional and A 2 : [0; 0] 7 ! R n2n is a piecewise continuous function. Due to the term A 2 () the system has a distributed delay in the sense of [11] (information needed on a whole delay interval, and not only to a given past value).
For the sake of simplicity, we shall first consider A2() constant. The system (13) becomes

If both A1 and A2 are not zero, we have a point + distributed delay system [14], and if A 1 is zero a distributed delay system (see also below), respectively. ds 0 x(s) T 0()x(s) + I1(x(s); x(s 0 1)) + I 2 (x(s); x(s + )) ds where 0 1 () is given by ( 16) and I1(x(t); x(t 0 1)) = [S 01 1 A T 1 P x(t) 0 x(t 0 1)] T S1 2 [S 01 1 A T 1 P x(t) 0 x(t 0 1 )]

x(s) T C T Cx(s) ds 0 1 2 V (0) 0 1 2 t 0 y(s) T y(s) ds 8 t > 0 (24) which completes the proof. Remark 3: The Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional candidate (18) has been already used in the control literature for deriving mixed delayindependent/delay-dependent stability results, using some appropriate fixed model transformations of the original system combined with appropriate matrix inequalities for estimating bounds on the Lyapunov's derivative [7], [21], [24]. More details about the connections between model transformations and Lyapunov's second method are given in [12]. Further comments on the construction of such Lyapunov functionals can be found in [13].

Remark 4: The presence of a distributed delay term in the system (15) imposes extra constraints in the solution of inequality (16). Note that, for = 0 or A 2 = 0, we recover the previous case having only a point state delay. Thus, if A 2 = 0, the matrix S 2 should be chosen zero, or arbitrarily small in norm, etc.
In the case of a "pure" distributed delay system of the form
div.formula: _ x(t) = Ax(t) + 0 0 A2x(t + ) d + Bu(t) y(t) = Cx(t)(25)
div.p: Lemma 2 becomes the following. x(s) T S(t 0 s)x(s) ds:

Remark 5: Note that the Lyapunov-Krasovskii candidate ( 32) is a natural extension of the Lyapunov functional (5), and the proof follows the same steps as the proof in Lemma 1, but using the monotonicity of the matrix function S(1) given by (29).

Remark 6: There are no other restrictions for constructing the function S(1). The idea is that the symmetric matrix S(1) should be positive definite for all argument values, but with a negative derivative allowing thus a nonincreasing Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional candidate. It seems clear that the nonlinear dependence in A 2 (1) gives the "best" choice of the corresponding term in the Lyapunov-Krasovskii candidate for "completing the square" in the derivative.

div.head: V. NUMERICAL EXAMPLES
div.p: We shall consider two examples of first and second order. Example 1: First, consider the same scalar case example as in [15] and [16]:
under an appropriate initial condition defined on the interval [0; 0]; x 2 R, > 0, and a 1 ; a 2 are real numbers. The corresponding transfer function is
div.formula: Y (s) U (s) = 1 s + a 1 + a 2 e 0s :
div.p: Using the proposed approach, and assuming ja1j ja2j, with a1 > 0 and a 1 + a 2 > 0, then 1) for any output-strictly passive and stable SISO system, the closed-loop system is strictly delay-independent passive; 2) the system (33) is delay-independent passive if ja 1 j > ja 2 j. Consider first the system with u 0. Note that by using the Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional V (x t ) = x(t) 2 + 0 0 x(t + ) 2 d simple computations prove that a 1 > 0, a 1 + a 2 > 0, ja 1 j > ja 2 j are sufficient conditions for delay-independent asymptotic stability in the case u 0. The derived condition is "close" to the necessary and sufficient one, which is given by: ja1j ja2j, under a1 + a2 > 0, a1 > 0 [9], [22], which can be derived using a LaSalle type argument [22] due to the definition of the Lyapunov derivative.

Based on the remarks above, condition 2) follows naturally. Note that it can also be found in [16] using a different proof argument. In the case ja 1 j > ja 2 j, the Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional (5) does not guarantee the passivity of the system. However, any output-strictly passive and stable SISO system connected with the transfer above induces the property for the closed-loop scheme.

motivated by the analysis of some combustion dynamics. Further details and remarks on the closed-loop schemes can be found in [6] and the references therein.

If we are interested on the passivity of the system, it follows that choosing = 0 and " = minf2a 1 ; a 2 g.
The system is passive if a 1 > 0 a2 > 0 c 2 < a 2 2 :
(35) Furthermore, if 6 = 0, then c can be larger, and the system can become passive in the sense of [18]. The same strategy can be used for more complicated systems.

Remark 7: Similar arguments can be used for the bilateral teleoperating scheme proposed in [5]. The corresponding delay-independent result was also derived using a different (frequency-based) argument. For the sake of brevity, we have not considered the corresponding case study here.

div.head: VI. CONCLUDING REMARKS
div.p: In this note, the passivity problem of a class of linear systems including (point or distributed) delayed state has been addressed. Sufficient conditions for passivity have been derived in terms of solutions of appropriate algebraic Riccati equations. The results are simple to check, and can be extended to multiple or time-varying delays.

div.head: A Nearly Interpolatory Algorithm for Identification with Mixed Time and Frequency Response Data
Guoxiang Gu and Jie Chen
div.p: Abstract-A new algorithm is proposed for identification with mixed-time and frequency-response data. This algorithm shares similar properties to interpolatory algorithms, and is nearly interpolatory. Meanwhile, it greatly reduces the computational complexity of the interpolatory algorithm. Worst-case identification error bounds are also characterized, and derived for this nearly interpolatory algorithm. A numerical example is used to illustrate the proposed identification algorithm. Index Terms-Discrete-time systems, frequency response, identification, interpolatory algorithm, time response.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Since the work of Helmicki, Jacobson, and Nett [11], the research area of H 1 identification has made much progress. Although the initial work has focused on the two-stage nonlinear algorithm [9], [11], [14] with frequency response data, interpolatory algorithms [3]- [5], [10], [13] gradually gained more recognition due to its essentially optimal identification error (within a factor of two). An interpolatory algorithm was also developed in [5] for H1 identification with time response data.

In this note, we consider H1 identification with mixed time and frequency response data, which was initially tackled in [13]. An interpolatory algorithm was proposed in [13] to seek the identified model. Similar to [3]- [5], the interpolatory algorithm consists of two steps: first solve a data consistency problem which determines whether or not the a posteriori data are consistent with the a priori information; and second construct an interpolatory model, if the answer to the first one is positive. Again the data consistency problem is an equivalent LMI feasibility problem, and there are standard solution methods and software packages available [2], [7]. The interpolatory model can be constructed using the procedure as outlined in [1], which in special cases reduces to Nevanlinna-Pick or Carathéodory-Fejér interpolation-the main tool for the interpolatory algorithm with frequency or time response data respectively.

While the interpolatory algorithm presents a viable approach to H 1 identification, and is essentially optimal within a factor of two [3] for its associated identification error, the corresponding computational complexity is high for both the data consistency problem, and the construction of the interpolatory model. This is the main motivation for the suboptimal algorithm proposed in [8] as an alternative to the interpolatory algorithm in [3], [10] where only frequency response data are used. Our goal in this note is to generalize the results in [8] to the case of mixed time and frequency response data so that the computationally prohibitive interpolatory algorithm can be replaced by a much simpler one with much lower computational complexity. This can indeed be achieved. To accomplish this goal, we propose a nearly in-
